close_symbols: OS_object_table (or the global object table/array(s) referenced by the ObjectId functions)
object name / buffer definitions and size constants used by the ObjectId functions (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME or similar)
explanation:
For a MISRA <string.h> bounds analysis you must inspect the target function and any transitive callees that could call string functions or manipulate buffers. The required symbols and why:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Direct callee of OS_CountSemTake; its implementation must be inspected for any string.h calls or buffer accesses.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Direct callees of OS_ObjectIdGetById; they may perform token/index conversions and name/buffer handling and thus may call string functions or access buffers.
- OS_CountSemTake_Impl: Called by the target; its body must be inspected for string usage or buffer access.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Callee of OS_CountSemTake_Impl; may access object arrays/buffers derived from tokens.
- OS_object_token_t, osal_id_t: Types used in the target and in the object-id machinery; required to understand pointer/structure layouts and whether string functions act on embedded char arrays or pointers.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_SUCCESS: Macro/constant parameters that influence the control flow inside OS_ObjectIdGetById and related functions (may select different code paths that do or do not use string functions).
- OS_object_table (or equivalent global object table/array(s)): The object-id functions typically index into global object tables or name buffers; you must inspect these definitions (arrays, element types, embedded name buffers and their sizes) to determine whether string operations can overflow.
- object name / buffer definitions and size constants (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME): Needed to check buffer lengths used with strncpy/memcpy/etc and validate arguments to string functions.
- memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn: The standard string functions covered by the MISRA rule — include these so the analyzer can look for direct or indirect calls to them and verify their call sites and argument sizes.
- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These unit-test/stub infrastructure functions appear in the static call graph for OS_CountSemTake. If present in the build, their instrumentation can introduce string operations or alter control flow; include them for completeness so the analyzer can determine whether any string functions originate from test-stub code.

Using these symbols the next agent can open the implementations, inspect any calls to the listed string functions, and verify that source and destination buffer sizes and indices (object table lookups, token conversions) cannot result in out-of-bounds accesses as required by the MISRA rule.
